Hey @GCinellu 

Unfortunately when typing `npm install` the in npm 1 & 2 the peerDependencies are installed as well. By removing them I could make sure the setup allows to make changes to Belle while instantly reviewing them in the `examples` playground or `docs`.

According to the docs npm 3 won't have these issues:

```
NOTE: npm versions 1 and 2 will automatically install peerDependencies if they are not
explicitly depended upon higher in the dependency tree. In the next major version of
npm (npm@3), this will no longer be the case. You will receive a warning that the
peerDependency is not installed instead. 
```

https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json
http://blog.npmjs.org/post/110924823920/npm-weekly-5

I'm happy to merge any pull-request that improves the situation, but for now I'm not sure how.

regarding focus settings: I will continue on the bootstrap theme today. I think this will have a big impact on the API design.

One way to deal with it could by leaving out children completely like `<Option value="some text" />`. The downside here would be a lot of checking & complexity is needed.

On alternative thing I though of for the select was introducing a second component:

```
<TextSelect options={[ 'Apple', 'Banana', 'Cherry' ]}>
```

In this case we could even leverage the native select implementations on mobile devices:
http://media.mediatemple.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/mobileinputs5.jpg

This would restrict us in terms of customizing the options, like we have we have done using images and sub-titles.

In general, I find the "one-time" focus animation to be visually interesting at the cost of accessibility. It's too easy to lose track of what is focused when the style doesn't stick around.

Yep, we kind of felt that while we were writing those styles, but then there are sites like youtube which use focus style which stays for short while.

That is why we kept it so configurable. You can always turn them off. Check out components on this link with classical focus styles: http://nikgraf.github.io/belle/#/configuration?theme=belle-with-default-focus

I think accessibility should be promoted by making this behavior the default and save the flair to be shown off in a theme. Otherwise, it could be seen as encouraging questionable practices. The configurability to allow either is definitely nice though.

Main question here: What value can we add compared to <input type="number">?

My first guess is: We can provide a nicer interface for editing numbers. Yet I'm not sure what's a great a experience. It also might very different depending on the range or if decimals are allowed/not allowed.

There are list of helpful attributes: `min`, `max`, `step` and `inputmode="numberic"`.

Important UX requirements:
- On Mobile devices we should show a numbers keypad if available
- Formatting/localisation should be supported
- Should the user be able to type characters? Do we show a warning or prevent it?

Thx to @ungerik for his feedback

Proposed rules:
- The next version is developed on the `develop` branch. I don't like the complexity of git flow, but it kind of makes sense for developing a library. http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/
- We still want to release often even if it's a small fix.
- We should have Changelog. Pull requests should update the changelog as well.
- Be there for questions in http://www.reactiflux.com/ (do we need Gitter then?)

Thoughts? Anything else? @jpuri

It would be nice to have some guidelines for contributors also.

We could have thought of some other git workflows more customized to our needs. Bit I think get flow is more of standard now, which everyone is comfortable using.
Great :smile:

On Sat, Jul 18, 2015 at 9:19 AM, Nikolaus Graf notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Should the user be able to type characters? Do we show a warning or
> prevent it?

It's not necessary to allow characters except for comma dot etc. depending
on the number format.

To allow natural editing it is necessary to accept user input, that is not
a valid number temporarily.

For example imagine someone is editing: "3.14".

He may add a point at a different position: "3.1.4"

And then remove the other point: "31.4"

Should that be supported, or should the user be forced to remove the other
point first?

Other cases are more easy to parse as valid numbers, even when digits are
missing: ".14" and "3." But in those cases the point must not be removed
while editing (which would happen if you parse and reset the number to
valid float in a bound input field)

Finding: in docs we are using highlightJs for highlighting the code. When we type a lot in controlled `<TextInput>` render is called multiple times and these code blocks are rendered again and again, this is adding crazy number of elements to dom and slowing down the page.

The issue disappears if I comment these highlightJs calls.

I researched a bit more regarding ComboBox and as defined by the W3C consortium the combobox is a subclass of a select tag.

"A presentation of a select; usually similar to a textbox where users can type ahead to select an option, or type to enter arbitrary text as a new item in the list. See related listbox."
http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/complete#combobox

To me this implies it should behave like one. Meaning the onUpdate should only be triggered in case an exact match happened. Unfortunately this will break our existing API, but I think it's better to do it now than later.

You might wonder what about the other use-cases when ComboBox is used like a Google. This is already possible by providing `inputProps.onChange` and listen to this one. We could add `inputProps.onUpdate` but I don't feel it's necessary.

@jpuri What do you think?

Nice research Nik,

We have components which are like blend of 2 others like rating something between a button and a form component.

This is how W3C definition of combobox goes - "A presentation of a select; usually similar to a textbox where users can type ahead to select an option, or type to enter arbitrary text as a new item in the list. See related listbox. combobox is the combined presentation of a single line textfield with a listbox popup. The combobox may be editable. Typically editable combo boxes are used for autocomplete behavior, and authors SHOULD set aria-autocomplete attribute on the textfield."

Its actually blend of select and input, this makes tough to decide the api. I do not want to go by the name 'ComboBox' or definition to design api, but want to create something that would fit need of web development and users of belle as of now - its our chance to do it better than w3c :smile: 

I think best way out is have 2 methods:
1. Triggered for exact match
2. Trigger for every change - for this we can not depend on onChange of React's `<input>` as it will not be triggered when user selects an option.

We can give any names in our api to these methods.

You can check this events in typeahead.js: https://github.com/twitter/typeahead.js/blob/master/doc/jquery_typeahead.md#custom-events

It has events for both input and select. I do not mind breaking the api, but what new we design should be great.

How about methods names like 
1. onUpdate - for any change
2. onSelect / onSelectionChange - for exact match
Might be a good base https://github.com/gaearon/library-boilerplate

We might need to rethink upon 'onInputMatch' implemented as of now, the use case I see problematic is if suppose we have 4 options like 
1. test
2. testing
3. testing12
4. testing12345

As soon as user types 'test' function 'onInputMatch' will be called. Might be user intended to type 'test' and then select 'testing12345'.

I think like typeadhead.js we call these callbacks only if user selects or autocompletes using hint one of the options. User may type whole values but then its developers job to handle these scenarios in 'onUpdate'.

Use cases we want to cover:

a. A field where the users needs to select a valid options (Pick a Country)
b. A search field with suggestions like google (just as help, but doesn't effect the output)
c. A search field where in case of a perfect match a redirect to the entry happens, otherwise a search page with alternative pages open
d. A search field where in case of a select from an option a redirect to the entry happens, otherwise a search page with possible entries open

## Proposal 1

onUpdate (fires whenever the input changes)
onExactMatch (fires when an option has chosen or the input match happend)

a.

```
<ComboBox onExactMatch={ (event) => { _chooseOption(event.identifier) }}>
  <Option value="Alaska" identifier={ 1 }>Alaska</Option>
  <Option value="California"  identifier={ 2 }>California</Option>
</ComboBox>
```

b.

```
<ComboBox onUpdate={ (event) => { _updateSearchTerm(event.value) }}>
  <Option value="Alaska">Alaska</Option>
  <Option value="California">California</Option>
</ComboBox>
```

c.

no idea, but probably super complex? We would somehow need to know which fires first and then sync those events.

d.

no idea, but probably super complex? We could add another method to only fire when something is selected, but it doesn't help

## Proposal 2

onUpdate (fires whenever a select/exact match happens)
inputProps.onUpdate (fires when input changes including select)

a.

```
<ComboBox onUpdate={ (event) => { _chooseOption(event.identifier) }}>
  <Option value="Alaska" identifier={ 1 }>Alaska</Option>
  <Option value="California"  identifier={ 2 }>California</Option>
</ComboBox>
```

b.

```
<ComboBox inputProps={{ onUpdate: (event) => { _updateSearchTerm(event.value) }}}>
  <Option value="Alaska">Alaska</Option>
  <Option value="California">California</Option>
</ComboBox>
```

c.

no idea, but probably super complex? We would somehow need to know which fires first and then sync those events.

d.

no idea, but probably super complex? We could add another method to only fire when something is selected, but it doesn't help

## Proposal 3

onUpdate (fires whenever the input changes, in case of a perfect match the optionMatch is set to true, in case an option has been selected optionSelect is set to true)

```
onUpdate({
  value: 'weee',
  identifier: 1
  optionMatch: true/false, (not sure about the name here)
  optionSelect: true/false (not sure about the name here)
})
```

a.

```
<ComboBox onUpdate={ (event) => { if (event.optionMatch) { _chooseOption(event.identifier) }}}>
  <Option value="Alaska" identifier={ 1 }>Alaska</Option>
  <Option value="California"  identifier={ 2 }>California</Option>
</ComboBox>
```

b.

```
<ComboBox onUpdate={ (event) => { _updateSearchTerm(event.value) }}>
  <Option value="Alaska">Alaska</Option>
  <Option value="California">California</Option>
</ComboBox>
```

c.

```
<ComboBox onUpdate={ (event) => {
    if (event.optionMatch) {
      _redirectToEntry(event.identifier)
    } else {
      _updateSearchTerm(event.value)
    }}}>
  <Option value="Alaska" identifier={ 1 }>Alaska</Option>
  <Option value="California"  identifier={ 2 }>California</Option>
</ComboBox>
```

d.

```
<ComboBox onUpdate={ (event) => {
    if (event.optionSelect) {
      _redirectToEntry(event.identifier)
    } else {
      _updateSearchTerm(event.value)
    }}}>
  <Option value="Alaska" identifier={ 1 }>Alaska</Option>
  <Option value="California" identifier={ 2 }>California</Option>
</ComboBox>
```

How do you feel about these proposal? Which one do you like more? Which one you don't? Feel free to add use-cases or other proposals. @jpuri

Hey Nik,

My implementation of helpers is not underscore, underscore takes care of a hell lot of edge cases and ECMA versions. I want to keep implementation minimal and tailored specifically to our need.

It definitely can be handled the way you are mentioning. But if we change helpers it will be change in one centralized place (it will not be ideal to need to do this for all props of type array :( ). I want to have clear expectation set from helper methods and all helper methods should behave in that way.

By moving away from underscore we definitely are losing advantage of battle tested code. But reverse engineering a helpers for us from underscore is crazy plus we might still be left with unexpected behaviors and doing some of the handling in components code itself.

> Would it be possible that we miss a render (which should happen) due this change?

`filteredOptions` is a derivative of some props and state. It's value should be a [pure function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pure_function) of `value`, `children`, `filterFunc` and `maxOptions`.

We could even make that explicit in the code by moving from a `filteredOptions` variable to a `getFilteredOptions()`-function. For performance reasons you should probably [memoize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memoization) that function.

If the statement above is correct then any change to the input of that function might cause `filteredOptions` to change and should cause a re-render. But because it's input is from state and props changes already cause the component to re-render, so we won't miss a render.

We already know specific places where filteredOptions can change, so I think calling function at just those places might be more performant than memoize and calling at each render.

Mostly its called only when inputValue changes and in that case re-filtering is actually needed.

The reason I mentio the `getFilteredOptions` and memoizing alternative is mostly to explain how you could see it as derived state and why I think it is correct to not have it trigger a rerender by itself.

The alternative will probably only be slower if the _"is it cached"_-check is particulary heavy (which I don't think it is) but there is not real need to actually go that route, given that the current implementation (with this fix) works fine.

I debug the issue in radium + belle, and it came out that out 2 components - Select / ComboBox are not working well with radium. These components are structured like: ``` ``` Select code expects to get an array of the nested components in props.children: But with radium this array is converted to object: This is breaking the 2 components :(

This isn't a Radium bug; belle should never manipulate this.props.children directly (e.g. by expecting it to be an array). Only the React.Children helpers should be used: https://facebook.github.io/react/docs/top-level-api.html#react.children.

@LucaColonnello honestly we are not sure yet - we did a brainstorming for mobile navigation most recently:

## On Mobile
1. Slide the main page to the right (sometimes left). This is becoming popular and feels pretty good. This navigation field is even scrollable. I like Slack's version on iOS where you have search bar on top.
   You can grab the menu. If you slide it it will complete the slide, but as like with the toggle you can grab it and move it from left to right and back.

![slack_for_ios_upload](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/223045/9362843/364b6a98-46a3-11e5-984c-8572cb0b9a67.jpg)
1. Also very popular the burger menu like Bootstrap3 has it. It's a one time animation to open & close it. It is not positioned absolute, but rather moves the content down. This is especially nice in case the list is longer than the screen.

![slack_for_ios_upload 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/223045/9362850/3b0d0a28-46a3-11e5-9b72-59a011994c79.jpg)
1. In Angular Material you see the Navigation fading in from the left and overlaying the content. It's an animation you can't control. If you click a Navigation entry or click on the small content area if changes the content and fades the navigation area back.

![slack_for_ios_upload 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/223045/9362852/40b4a846-46a3-11e5-90ee-98a5571727a3.jpg)

## On Desktop
1. Very common is a top navigation. Some have dropdowns e.g. Google, Facebook.
2. Sometimes you get the same left navigations as with on mobile devices, but because of the larger screen it's always visible.

## Open Questions
- What are the event handlers?
- How does it move the content? Does the content need a special wrapper tag to make sure the styling works fine or is it not problem?
- For menu of type-1 above, if someone is using on desktop, how will user drag it in. User may end-up resizing the browser rather. <- like on Slack app or our toggle a simple tap or click is good enough to slide it. No need to slide it all the way.

## Notes

The first one (Slack like) looks good on Mobile and might also look good on Desktop. What happens if someone wants to have a top nav on desktop and the left sided menu on mobile.
Should be pretty easy. We can provide an example based on responsive design to switch between.

We would need to provide users with couple of nav designs:
1. Simple link
2. Dropdown with multiple options
3. Expandable links

Open question: How do they play with react-router?!? We need to investigate there.

I like the idea of having the simple navigation component which is just taking care of left/right sliding. People can use their own links or if they want to leverage the ready to use design of belle the can use our simple link, drowns & expandable link components like described above.

Possible names: `<LeftNavigation>, <Navigation>, <Nav>, <LeftNav>, <MobileNav>, <SlideNavigation>, <SlideNav>`

```
<Navigation>
   <NavLink>Home</NavLink>
   <NavGroup> // expandable
      <NavTitle>Components</NavTitle>
      <NavLink>Button</NavLink>
      <NavLink>ComboBox</NavLink>
   </NavGroup>
  <NavDivider/> or <NavSeparator/>
</Navigation>
```

Inspriations: https://www.google.com/design/spec/patterns/navigation-drawer.html#

Hi @Agamennon, thanks for asking. In case we didn't miss anything we do expose all `onChange`, `onFocus` and so on. It's true that we don't expose onChange, but instead you can use `onUpdate`. This is, because simulating onChange properly would have increased component's complexity a lot and even React core contributors don't recommend it. See a longer explanation here: https://github.com/nikgraf/belle/issues/58/.

I would be happy to help you out. Maybe you can post an example of what you want to achieve and we can work it out together. Here an example using `onUpdate`:

```
<Select onUpdate={ (event) => console.log(event.value) }>
  <Option value={ "vienna" }>Vienna</Option>
  <Option value={ "rome" }>Rome</Option>
</Select>
```

I have common use-case: for example I'm using SASS (Stylus, PostCSS, whatever) to manage my styles. And actually I like the idea of managing styles in stylesheets using [css-modules](https://github.com/css-modules/css-modules), outside of markup and jsx, where long styles become pretty noisy.

1) about grid, i saw and try alot of js grids, but my experience tells me that in 80% you will need common table with sorting, paging, actions (e.g. last column with buttons), template for row/cell output, columns setup (e.g. cols/rowspan, multiline columns) and some kind of 'bulk actions' - like checkbox all rows and etc. 

2) Yes, often grids also needs a filter, but in most cases it's only at demo you can see built-in filter in columns, but in real world it's almost useless and you will need more complex way to filter data, like few criteria for same attribute of model (with differ operand OR/AND). So in most cases i had to create from ground a external filter for grid and exclude built-in filters. So for that feature i would think about separate component with ability to "bind" to grid.

3) More advanced grids also let you to use some column settings, e.g.: resize, show/hide and etc, BUT it's like extra feature that can be missed, but not critical.

4) some advanced grids also let you inline editing, but my experience tells me that in real world, in most cases it's better to edit via external editor, maybe at modal window. 

5) server-side integration to get data from server

6) maybe it's good idea to think about 'data provider' that can be used at data related components - select, grids, suggest, forms and etc.

So i would like to stick with features from (1) and (5) and maybe (6)

P.S.: of course serve-side integration for grid is must have feature.

P.P.S.: Ok, i will wait till draft of 3.0.0 and "test component" to join :)

Regarding your suggestions, @felix-d:
- React confusingly treats "key" differently from other props. You can't access it from `this.props`.
- An "id" prop would absolutely solve this issue! It would be a bit painful to require an "id" (or similar) prop for every component when you want server side rendering, though.

Here's two similar ways of solving this:
- We could make style IDs based on a hash of the computed style. Multiple components with the same style would have the same hash, and we would have to update the hash whenever the style changes. We would need to reference count each hash globally. I'm not sure what having to change class names when styles change would do for performance. Hopefully, not much?
- We could generate hashes after the component mounts. The downside here is we would have to either manually add class names or rerender, neither of which seem quite "right".

I'd be interested in implementing the style-hash ID approach. Am I missing another way? Thoughts, @felix-d and @nikgraf?

@mcbryant 

> An "id" prop would absolutely solve this issue! It would be a bit painful to require an "id" (or similar) prop for every component when you want server side rendering, though.

This is what Material UI does AFAIK. 

The hashing solution seems like a good idea but it's more complex. I'd go with the `id` solution first to fix the issue, and then maybe think about an alternative solution that involves hashing, but the `id` solution is quite viable and solid 👍 Simple is always better than complex 😄 

Good reasoning!
